definitions.definition: the empty space at the side of a written or printed page

examples.text: the **left-hand/right-hand margin**
a **narrow/wide margin**
notes scribbled in the margin

definitions.definition: the amount of time, or number of votes, etc. by which somebody wins something

examples.text: He won by a **narrow margin**.
She beat the other runners by a margin of ten seconds.
Members voted by a margin of 7–1 to become a public limited company.
He had an 18-second margin over his nearest rival.
She won by the narrowest of margins.
The amendment passed by an overwhelming margin.
The election is likely to be decided by razor-thin margins.
The winning margin was only 8 seconds.

phrases: by the largest, narrowest, etc. of margins

definitions.definition: the difference between the cost of buying or producing something and the price that it is sold for

examples.text: What are your average operating margins?
a gross margin of 45 per cent
How does the company get by with such razor-thin margins?
The company relies on fat margins from luxury models.
They are operating at very low margins.
They hope to improve their margins on computers.

definitions.definition: an extra amount of something such as time, space, money, etc. that you include in order to make sure that something is successful

examples.text: a safety margin
The narrow gateway left me little **margin for error** as I reversed the car.
The schedule left no margin for error.
We have substantial reserves, which provide a good margin for uncertainties.

definitions.definition: the extreme edge or limit of a place

examples.text: the eastern margin of the Indian Ocean

definitions.definition: the part that is not included in the main part of a group or situation

examples.text: people living on the margins of society

definitions.definition: an amount that is added to a basic wage, paid for special skill or responsibility

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin margo, margin- ‘edge’.
